Open Ponds Western Trailhead
36 words (Â½ minute)
The western trailhead of the Open Ponds Trail begins at the far eastern end of the Frisco Campground. No parking is available at the trailhead, but there is limited parking at the entrance of the campground.

End of message.

title: Oregon Inlet Boat Launch
listingDescription: This boat launch has five non-slip ramps, five finger piers, and one ADA-compliant floating dock. There is no fee to launch boats from this facility. There is ample parking for vehicles and trailers, with 77 large parking spaces and 2 accessible parking spaces closer to the restroom facility. There is a nearby restroom facility at the southeast corner of the parking area, which is also where a drinking fountain and water bottle filling station is located.

images.altText: Non-slip ramps leading down into the marina waters with finger piers between.
images.caption: Boat ramps

bodyText:
This boat launch has five non-slip ramps, five finger piers, and one ADA-compliant floating dock. There is no fee to launch boats from this facility.

There is ample parking for vehicles and trailers, with 77 large parking spaces and 2 accessible parking spaces closer to the restroom facility. There is a nearby restroom facility at the southeast corner of the parking area, which is also where a drinking fountain and water bottle filling station is located. A trash and recycling station can be found to the east of the boat launches.
audioDescription:
Oregon Inlet Boat Launch
43 words (Â½ minute)
The boat launch is located behind the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center, and there is plenty of parking for vehicles and trailers. Note that restrooms are located in a separate building, accessible from the boat launch parking lot, behind the mounted fish display cases.

End of message.

title: Oregon Inlet Fishing Center
listingDescription: Oregon Inlet Fishing Center (a concessionaire within the park) is a full-service marina where a fishing expedition of your dreams can be chartered. Over 40 boats are available for chartering a variety of fishing opportunities, be it out in the Gulf Stream or in the Pamlico Sound. Additional details can be found at oregon-inlet.com .For those who bring their own boats, there is a free boat launch and parking area available behind the fishing center building.There are parking

images.altText: Several charter fishing boats are lined up in the marina
images.caption: Charter fishing fleet

bodyText:
Oregon Inlet Fishing Center (managed through a lease) is a full-service marina where a fishing expedition of your dreams can be chartered. Over 40 boats are available for chartering a variety of fishing opportunities, be it out in the Gulf Stream or in the Pamlico Sound. Additional details can be found at oregon-inlet.com.

For those who bring their own boats, there is a free boat launch and parking area available behind the fishing center building.

There are parking spaces surrounding the marina and in front of the fishing center, including 5 accessible spaces at the fishing center. The restroom facility, with a drinking fountain and water bottle filling station, is located just to the north of the fishing center. A recycling station can be found next to the trophy display case that also stands north of the fishing center.

Oregon Inlet

Oregon Inlet is an area of open water that connects the Atlantic Ocean and the Pamlico Sound, providing a route to get out and explore the ocean waters.

Like most all of the past and present inlets along the Outer Banks, Oregon Inlet was created when a hurricane passed through the area. In 1846 the hurricane created a wide, watery gash between present-day Bodie Island and Pea Island. During the storm, a ship that was caught in the Pamlico Sound, the Oregon, witnessed the sudden formation of the new inlet. After the storm had passed, the crew spread the word of the new, wide inlet that now separated Hatteras Island from the rest of the Outer Banks. As a result of their initial accounts, the inlet was named after this ship.

At 2.5 miles wide, Oregon Inlet is one of the larger Outer Banks inlets, but that distance changes regularly with shifting sand bars, and incoming or outgoing tides.
audioDescription:
Oregon Inlet Fishing Center
131 words (1-Â¼ minute)
There is a long, one-story pale blue, wooden building here with a well-stocked store selling ice, fishing and camping supplies, clothing, boating equipment, and food and beverages. Just to the north of the fishing center are also several large outdoor display cases of mounted fish caught in the surrounding waters, including a world-record Atlantic Blue Marlin caught on July 26, 1974. It was 166 inches long and weighed 1,142 pounds.

The National Park Service maintains a boat launch behind the center, and there is plenty of parking for vehicles and trailers both around the marina and near the boat launch. Note that restrooms are located in a separate building, accessible from both the boat ramp parking lot and the fishing center area, behind the mounted fish display cases.

End of message.

title: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
listingDescription: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch at the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center provide a safe and easy way to launch a kayak to explore Pamlico Sound.

images.altText: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
images.title: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch
images.caption: Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch

bodyText:
The Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch, located at the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center on Bodie Island, provides a great opportunity to put kayaks into the water. Ample parking, loading areas, and maintaned path to Pamlico Sound create an easy access to Pamlico Sound and Oregon Inlet.

Pamlico Sound is an enjoyable place for kayaking, but strong currents and waves can turn a fun visit into a frightening one. Kayaking in the area requires planning and attentiveness- Pamlico Sound and Oregon Inlet serve as a vital artery for fishing boats. Be mindful of vessels, and constantly monitor for their wakes. Always be aware of changing tides and ocean conditions.

The Oregon Inlet Kayak Launch was made possible by support from Outer Banks Forever, Towne Bank, Atlantic Rentals, and Bass Pro Shops.

Kayaking Safely

  • Do not kayak during thunderstorms.
  • Research local hazards and weather, avoid colisions.
  • Bring essential safety gear such as personal floatation devices for everonye onboard, whistle, and a communicaton device.
  • Dress for water immersion, and be aware of hypothermia.
  • Share your plan with a family member or friend.
  • Plan an trip within your capabilities- distances can be deceiving.
audioDescription: Enter the Oregon Inlet Fishing Center at the base of the Basnight Bridge, and take an immediate left to the charter boat marina. Stay on the east side of the marina and drive to the end of the pavement. The kayak launch is at the south end of the parking lot.

title: Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center
listingDescription: Since 1938, Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge has provided an area for migratory birds to rest, nest, and winter. This is a birder hotspot! The list of migratory birds that use the refuge at any point in the year is very lengthly, but includes: waterfowl like snow geese and various duck species, shorebirds like sanderlings and terns, wading birds like egrets and herons, raptors like osprey and peregrine falcons, as well as, neotropical migrants. They also protect endangere

images.altText: Sea oats on the dunes are turned orange in the sunset, which also paints the sky shades of pink, orange, yellow, and blue.
images.caption: Sunset at Pea Island

bodyText:
Since 1938, Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge has provided an area for migratory birds to rest, nest, and winter. This is a birder hotspot! The list of migratory birds that use the refuge at any point in the year is very lengthly, but includes: waterfowl like snow geese and various duck species, shorebirds like sanderlings and terns, wading birds like egrets and herons, raptors like osprey and peregrine falcons, as well as, neotropical migrants. They also protect endangered and threaten species, which include American oystercatchers and loggerhead sea turtles.

Pea Island National Wildlife refuge is 13 miles in length, and encompasses 5,834 land acres plus 25,700 acres of "Proclamation Boundary waters." The visitor center has wildlife exhibits and information, knowledgeable staff and volunteers, items for sale, restroom facilities, an observation deck, and several trailheads.

A pedestrian crosswalk leads across NC-12 to the beach, where there is a view of the shipwreck The Oriental .
audioDescription:
Pea Island National Wildlife Refuge Visitor Center
279 words (2-Â½ minutes)
Located on the sound side of NC-12 at the north end of a parking lot, the visitor center is a raised, one-story wooden building accessible via a boardwalk ramp in front. Benches ring a 10 by 30 foot area at the top of the ramp at the right, while the entrance door to the building is to the left. To the right of the entrance is a table with a number of seashells, which you may touch.

Restrooms are located in a building at the south end of the 150-foot long parking lot. To get to the restrooms, move 35 feet along a concrete sidewalk at the far left side of the lot at the south, and turn right. The women's room is located eight feet ahead on the right, and the men's room is located 15 feet further along the sidewalk at the far end of the building on the right.

Visitors will also find several nature trails at this location. Known as part of the "Charles Kuralt Trail," after the distinguished radio and television journalist, access to the North Pond and Salt Flats Trails starts along a boardwalk about 10 feet further along the sidewalk leading from the lot.

Back at the north end of the lot, visitors may access a wide ocean beach on the other side of the NC-12 by carefully moving off a grassy area and continuing 25 feet across the highway crosswalk onto the sand. Moving 100 feet up a steep incline to the top of the dunes, the boiler and smokestack of the 1862 Oriental steamship wreck can be seen protruding from the surf about 150 feet offshore.

End of message.

title: Pole Road
listingDescription: Pole Road is an approximately 2-mile long off-road vehicle access route on the southern end of Hatteras Island that provides opportunities to visit various Atlantic Ocean and Pamlico Sound beach locations.

images.altText: A split in the sandy Pole Road with the signature poles visible to the right of the road.
images.caption: Poles and the Pole Road

bodyText:
Ramps are subject to closure. For the most current status of beach access ramps, go to https://go.nps.gov/beachaccess.

Pole Road is an approximately 2-mile long off-road vehicle access route on the southern end of Hatteras Island that provides opportunities to visit various Atlantic Ocean and Pamlico Sound beach locations.

Off-road Vehicle Use


For beaches open to off-road-vehicle use, an off-road vehicle permit is required. Annual permits (from date of purchase) are $120 and 10-day permits are $50. Vehicles must be licensed, insured and registered; you must present your driver's license and vehicle registration. Permits must be purchased online at Recreation.gov
audioDescription:
Pole Road
103 words (1 minute)
Pole Road is located at the end of a parking lot across the street from the Graveyard of the Atlantic Museum and the Hatteras Inlet North Ferry Terminal. From the lot, the road continues 50 feet forward onto the sand. A sign at the right reminds drivers that an off-road vehicle permit is required to drive onto the beach. The road forks to the right where two signs post the driving and beach regulations to which all must adhere. The road continues around to the right and provides sound access and several spots as it travels to the end of Hatteras Island.

End of message.ï»¿

title: Pony Pasture
listingDescription: Ocracoke's "ponies" are not really ponies at all, but true horses descended from domesticated Spanish mustangs. Legend has it that these animals, also known as Banker horses, were left here by shipwrecked explorers in the 16th or 17th century. The free-ranging animals were permanently penned in 1959 to prevent them from over-grazing the island's vegetation, and to safeguard them from traffic after the highway was built in 1957.Visitors can see the ponies from a wooden viewing

images.altText: A pony in a field with hay
images.title: Ocracoke Pony Pens
images.caption: Ocracoke Ponies are a neat surprise to see on the Island

bodyText:
Ocracoke's "ponies" are not really ponies at all, but true horses descended from domesticated Spanish mustangs. Legend has it that these animals, also known as Banker horses, were left here by shipwrecked explorers in the 16th or 17th century. The free-ranging animals were permanently penned in 1959 to prevent them from over-grazing the island's vegetation, and to safeguard them from traffic after the highway was built in 1957.

Visitors can see the ponies from a wooden viewing platform that rises above the double wooden pasture fence, or by following a boardwalk about Â¼-mile to a second raising viewing platform. There is a donation box (summer-only) to the left of the stairway, for those who wish to help support the care of these cultural icons. For those wishing to support the care during the winter months, please stop by the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center to make a donation in person.

From the parking lot, the beach is accessible from a boardwalk.

History of the Horses

Legend has it that the "Banker" horses of Ocracoke were left here by shipwrecked explorers in the 16th or 17th century. European ships commonly carried livestock to the "New World." If a ship ran aground near the coast, animals were thrown overboard to lighten the load so that the ship could be re-floated. The livestock were often left behind when the ship again set sail. Sir Richard Grenville's ship Tiger ran aground at Ocracoke in 1585. There is speculation that he may have unloaded Spanish mustangs on the island.

Horses have been documented on Ocracoke since the first European settlers came to stay in the 1730s. There have been as many as 300 horses on Ocracoke. While small and powerful, they are full-grown horses that are often called or referred to as "Banker" horses as their range included most of the Outer Banks. Physically, the Ocracoke horses are different from other horses-they have a different number of vertebrae and ribs as well as a distinct shape, posture, color, size, and weight that sets them apart.

The horses have played a major role in the island's history, serving residents as beasts of burden at work and play, in beach rides and races. When the early colonists settled Ocracoke, they used the ponies to help make life easier on the island by pulling carts to haul freight and fish. The US Life-saving Service used them for beach patrols and to haul equipment to shipwreck sites. The US Coast Guard kept a small band of "Banker" horses to patrol the beaches in World War II. As time progressed, the families that lived on the island claimed the horses, holding penning events in the summer. Riders would start early in the morning at the north end of the island and drive the horses into the village where holding pens had been constructed. Once the horses were in the pens, the villagers would sort out the horses and brand the new ones. Some horses would be broken for riding or sold, and the rest were turned loose to roam free again.
audioDescription:
Pony Pasture
126 words (1-Â¼ minutes)
Move eight steps up onto a 15-foot wide by six-foot deep deck with four-foot railings. The animals move in and around large, fenced-in areas ahead and to the left and right. There is a freshwater pond, some raised feeding troughs, and several wooden one-story buildings off in the distance.

Fifty yards off to the right is a second, smaller viewing platform. To get to this platform, move 80 feet along the boardwalk with the pasture on your left to where some tall bushes begin. Continue about 200 feet, following the boardwalk as it winds through marshland around to a ramp with four-foot high railings. Move 50 feet up a slight incline, turn left, and move 12 feet onto the platform.

End of message.

title: Pony Pasture Beach
listingDescription: For those wishing to enjoy the beach at this location, there is a large parking lot and pedestrian boardwalk. The boardwalk leads up and over the dunes to the beach. Near the parking lot are portable restroom facilities, as well as picnic tables on either side of the lot.

images.altText: waves crashing on a sandy beach
images.title: Pony Pasture Beach
images.caption: Pony Pasture Beach is a nice secluded beach to enjoy

bodyText:
Right across from the Ocracoke Pony Pens, is a great secluded beach that provides great views and tranquil scenery.  For those wishing to enjoy the beach at this location park across from the Ocracoke Pony Pens and use the pedestrian boardwalk. The boardwalk leads up and over the dunes to the beach. Near the parking lot are portable restroom facilities, as well as picnic tables on either side of the lot.

Know Before You Go

The seashore is an enjoyable place for swimming, but rough surf and rip currents can turn a fun visit into a frightening one. Tides, waves, and winds constantly barrage these barrier islands. Even at the shore's edge, crashing waves can pick you up and throw you to the sandy bottom causing injuries.
audioDescription:
Pony Pasture Beach
91 words (1 minute)
A pedestrian boardwalk that leads to the beach is located halfway along the southern edge of the parking lot. To the left of the boardwalk are two outdoor exhibits, titled "Know Before You Go" and "Journey of Sand." Note there are two portable restroom facilities 40 feet to the right.

To reach the beach, continue 270 feet forward up the boardwalk on a slight incline to a 15-foot square deck with some benches at the right. Carefully move forward to a staircase, and move 12 steps down onto the sand.

End of message.

title: Program Pavilion
listingDescription:
The pavilion is a wonderful place to catch a ranger program during the summer season, or to relax and take in the sight of Cape Hatteras Lighthouse from a shaded location.

Check the event schedule to see what ranger programs are available.

images.altText: View of the Interpretation Pavilion with the Cape Hatteras Lighthouse in the background.
images.caption: Pavilion and lighthouse

bodyText:
The pavilion is a wonderful place to catch a ranger program during the summer season, or to relax and take in the sight of Cape Hatteras Lighthouse from a shaded location.

Check the event schedule to see what ranger programs are available.
audioDescription:
Program Pavilion
187 words (1-Â¾ minutes)
Mindfully cross the loop road from the parking lot to a 50-foot wide patio area with several benches at the left and right. Continue 40 feet forward onto a wooden boardwalk and 30 feet up a slight incline to a 30-foot square, open arbor plaza. Six wooden benches occupy the center section of the plaza.

Turn right and move 15 feet and turn right to face the restrooms. The men's room is to the right down a short hallway, and there is a unisex restroom straight ahead. Ten feet to the left of the unisex room is a water fountain, and the women's room is located to the left of that down another short hallway. A second water fountain with a water bottle filling station and a pet fountain is located eight feet to the left of the ramp past a blue plastic recycling bin.

Continue 30 feet across the plaza into the covered, open air Interpretive Pavilion where various ranger talks and presentations take place. Six rows of low wooden benches fill the central area of the pavilion, facing the lighthouse to the right.

End of message.

title: Rodanthe Beach Access
listingDescription: Rodanthe Beach Access, provided by Dare County, is one of the only accessible public beach access in the Rodanthe, Waves, Salvo area of Hatteras Island. This is a great place for people staying in the area to access the beach easily.

images.altText: walkway and shade structure on the beach
images.title: Rodanthe Beach Access
images.caption: Rodanthe Beach Access

bodyText:
Rodanthe Beach Access, provided by Dare County, is one of the only accessible public beach access in the Rodanthe, Waves, Salvo area of Hatteras Island. From July 1 to August 11, 2023, National Park Service and Dare County will station lifeguards at the beach from 9am- 5pm.

FEATURES:

  • 97 parking spaces
  • Bathhouse
  • Outdoor Showers
  • Picnic tables
  • Oceanfront Gazebo
  • ADA compliant boardwalk to the dune top gazebo
audioDescription: Parking lot is located along NC Highway 12 in Rodanthe NC. From the highway, an access road will take you east to a large parking lot with beach access.

title: Salvo Soundside Beach
listingDescription: Salvo Day Use Area has sandy sound-front beaches, plenty of parking, and seasonally opened restroom facilities. The comfort station has two changing bays, an outdoor shower, and two pit-style restrooms.The area is ideal for watersport lovers, including kayakers, kiteboarders, windsurfers, and stand-up paddle boarders. It is also a good playground for young families, where the gentler, warmer waters of the Pamlico Sound are perfect for splashing around and playing in. There ar

images.altText: Dozens of visitors are playing in the waters of the Pamlico Sound or relaxing on a stretch of sandy beach.
images.caption: Visitors enjoying Pamlico Sound

bodyText:
Salvo Sound Access has sandy sound-front beaches, plenty of parking, and seasonally opened restroom facilities. The comfort station has two changing bays, an outdoor shower, and two pit-style restrooms.

The area is ideal for watersport lovers, including kayakers, kiteboarders, windsurfers, and stand-up paddle boarders. It is also a good playground for young families, where the gentler, warmer waters of the Pamlico Sound are perfect for splashing around and playing in. There are also picnic tables and metal grills available for those who wish to enjoy a meal outdoors.

A Nursery, A Haven, A Home

Beneath the surface of the Pamlico Sound is a nursery perfect for marine life. Fed by the ocean and mainland rivers, the sound is a mix of salt and fresh water that is just right for many species. This estuary and its marshes provide protection and shelter for eggs and young to hatch and grow.

Some animals will spend their entire lives here. Others are born in the ocean and travel through inlets into the sound to spend their adolescence before returning to the sea. Some adult fish come into the sound to deposit their eggs among the protective eelgrass. Once hatched, the young stay and grow before leaving the sound for the ocean - only to return, maybe years later, to continue the cycle.

- In the sound, food such as plankton, is readily available. Tall eelgrass gives shelter from the elements and predators.
- The grass shrimp, periwinkle snail, and fiddler crab are some of the animals that spend their entire lives in the Pamlico Sound.
- Some animals, like the red drum, flounder, bull shark, and clear-nosed skate are born in the sound and later live in the ocean.
- The American eel and the green sea turtle are examples of sea life that may go from the ocean to the sound during their lifetime.
audioDescription:
Salvo Day Use Area
245 words (2-Â¼ minutes)
There is a sandy path about halfway along the parking area closest to the Pamlico Sound.

At the start of the sandy path leading up the small hill toward the sound, stands an outdoor exhibit titled "A Nursery, A Haven, A Home." To get to the beach on the sound, move 30 feet up the sandy path to the top of the small rise. Note there are a number of picnic tables scattered about on the beach ahead of you, as well as to the left and right. There are also a number of fixed charcoal grilles placed in this area.

To get to the restroom and shower building, facing the sound, turn left and move off the far left side of the main parking lot onto a sand and grass area, and continue 120 feet to a one-story, gray and white, wooden building. Move onto a four-foot wide boardwalk surrounding a 15-foot square, tile floor shower area with a central shower station with multiple showerheads.

There are two accessible restrooms about six feet to the left of the shower area. The first is the men's room, followed by the women's room a few feet further on to the right.

There are also two changing rooms with swinging wood doors and benches located on the far side of the building. To get to the rooms, move to the far side of the tile floor and then down onto sand and turn left.

End of message.

title: Sandy Bay
listingDescription: Hatteras Island is very narrow at this point; no more than a few hundred feet wide! As such, Sandy Bay Day Use Area offers both sound- and ocean-side water recreation activities.Pamlico Sound is very shallow across its width, and tufts of vegetation can be seen peeking out above the water far out into the sound. It is often very windy here, however, making for excellent kiteboarding and windsurfing activities.

images.altText: Sandy path leads through the low-lying vegetation to the Pamlico Sound.
images.caption: Sandy path to the sound

bodyText:
Hatteras Island is very narrow at this point; no more than a few hundred feet wide! As such, Sandy Sound Access offers both sound- and ocean-side water recreation activities.

Pamlico Sound is very shallow across its width, and tufts of vegetation can be seen peeking out above the water far out into the sound. It is often very windy here, however, making for excellent kiteboarding and windsurfing activities. Meanwhile, the Atlantic Ocean waters at this point are influenced by the Gulf Stream.

This is a basic day use area, with 26 regular parking spaces, a boardwalk with steps leading across the dunes to the ocean beach, and no other amenities.

A Nursery, A Haven, A Home

Beneath the surface of the Pamlico Sound is a nursery perfect for marine life. Fed by the ocean and mainland rivers, the sound is a mix of salt and fresh water that is just right for many species. This estuary and its marshes provide protection and shelter for eggs and young to hatch and grow.

Some animals will spend their entire lives here. Others are born in the ocean and travel through inlets into the sound to spend their adolescence before returning to the sea. Some adult fish come into the sound to deposit their eggs among the protective eelgrass. Once hatched, the young stay and grow before leaving the sound for the ocean; only to return, maybe years later, to continue the cycle.

- In the sound, food such as plankton, is readily available. Tall eelgrass gives shelter from the elements and predators.
- The grass shrimp, periwinkle snail, and fiddler crab are some of the animals that spend their entire lives in the Pamlico Sound.
- Some animals, like the red drum, flounder, bull shark, and clear-nosed skate are born in the sound and later live in the ocean.
- The American eel and the green sea turtle are examples of sea life that may go from the ocean to the sound during their lifetime.
audioDescription:
Sandy Bay Day Use Area
167 words (1-Â½ minutes)
To reach the Pamlico Sound, move about 90 feet along a narrow sandy path from the parking lot to the sound. The beach here is very narrow with plenty of marshy vegetation all the way up to the water's edge.

To reach the ocean, from the middle of the parking lot move 25 feet off the asphalt across sandy ground to a white, painted crosswalk on the highway. Being mindful of traffic, move 30 feet across NC-12 and down onto the sand on the other side. Move 12 feet forward across the sand to a wooden staircase and up ten steps to a boardwalk with four-foot railings. Continue 40 feet up a slight incline where the ramp levels out, then move six more feet to the top of another set of stairs. Note the dunes to your left and right, smell the salty air, and listen to the crashing waves. Then move down 12 steps onto the beach itself. The Atlantic Ocean is directly ahead.

End of message.

title: Scarborough Family Cemetery
listingDescription: The Scarborough Family Cemetery is a small, roughly 20-foot square plot of land where Scarborough family members have been laid to rest. A white picket fence surrounds the cemetery.

images.altText: White picket fence surrounds the small family cemetery under the shade trees.
images.caption: Generations at rest

bodyText:
The Scarborough Family Cemetery is a small, roughly 20-foot square plot of land where Scarborough family members have been laid to rest. A white picket fence surrounds the cemetery.

Generations at Rest

Although it is uncommon today, before public or church cemeteries, families buried their dead on their own property. The Scarborough family once owned this property and this is their cemetery. As you walk around Ocracoke, you may notice several family cemeteries, some of which are still active. Remember to be respectful of these sacred places on private property.
audioDescription:
Scarborough Family Cemetery
54 words (Â½ minute)
Starting at the far end of the deck opposite the visitor center, move down six stairs onto a boardwalk and move 20 feet to the interpretive area at the left. Turn left and move 70 feet across uneven ground to a small cemetery with a picket fence with a sign titled "Generations at Rest."

End of message.

title: Silver Lake Harbor
listingDescription: Silver Lake Harbor is a clam-shaped basin on the sound-side of the island, around which the village of Ocracoke has grown.The harbor is usually bustling with boats, skiffs, sailboats, yachts, and ships. These boats range from the giant North Carolina state-run ferries to privately owned vessels just popping in for a tour or an elongated stay.Gorgeous sunsets over the harbor and Pamlico Sound are simply stunning, especially with the dozens of boats that inevitably return with

images.altText: View of the harbor and docks, with part of the village visible in the background, across the harbor.
images.caption: Silver Lake Harbor Docks

bodyText:
Silver Lake Harbor is a clam-shaped basin on the sound-side of the island, around which the village of Ocracoke has grown.

The harbor is usually bustling with boats, skiffs, sailboats, yachts, and ships. These boats range from the giant North Carolina state-run ferries to privately owned vessels just popping in for a tour or an elongated stay.

Gorgeous sunsets over the harbor and Pamlico Sound are simply stunning, especially with the dozens of boats that inevitably return with every sunset to dock up for the night.

Boat Slips

There are multiple slips for boats up to 80 feet long.
audioDescription:
Silver Lake Harbor Docks
80 words (Â¾ minute)
The docks are located across the street from the Ocracoke Island Visitor Center. Move ten feet from the back of the parking lot along a concrete path across a metal walkway, and continue onto a ten foot wide concrete sidewalk stretching to the left and right along the harbor-front. The NCDOT ferry docks are to the right. Several docks jut out into the water here, complete with utility hookup stations, along with occasional fire extinguisher and life preserver stations.

End of message.

title: Sound Access Ramp 46
listingDescription: Pamlico Sound is one of the largest estuarine ecosystems in the United States of America. The water in the sound is shallow, relative warm and calm, brackish, and teeming with biodiversity. Access to the Pamlico Sound provides a variety of recreation opportunities: bait-fishing, crabbing, kayaking, kiteboarding, nature viewing, stand-up paddling, wading, and wind surfing to name a few.

images.altText: Close-up of the wooden post with "46" carved into the top edges.
images.caption: Ramp 46

bodyText:
Ramps are subject to closure. For the most current status of beach access ramps, go to https://go.nps.gov/beachaccess.

Pamlico Sound is one of the largest estuarine ecosystems in the United States of America. The water in the sound is shallow, relative warm and calm, brackish, and teeming with biodiversity. Access to the Pamlico Sound provides a variety of recreation opportunities: bait-fishing, crabbing, kayaking, kiteboarding, nature viewing, stand-up paddling, wading, and wind surfing to name a few.

Besides enjoying the waters of the sound, be on the lookout for birds like great blue herons, white ibises, snowy egrets, rare white pelicans, and even American bald eagles-who make rare appearances on the forest borders.

Know Before You Go

The seashore is an enjoyable place for swimming, but rough surf and rip currents can turn a fun visit into a frightening one. Tides, waves, and winds constantly barrage these barrier islands. Even at the shore's edge, crashing waves can pick you up and throw you to the sandy bottom causing injuries.

Off-road Vehicle Use


For beaches open to off-road-vehicle use, an off-road vehicle permit is required. Annual permits (from date of purchase) are $120 and 10-day permits are $50. Vehicles must be licensed, insured and registered; you must present your driver's license and vehicle registration. Permits must be purchased online at Recreation.gov
audioDescription:
Sound Access Ramp 46
41 words (Â½ minute)
Sound Access Ramp 46 leads 80 feet across the sand through some scrub thicket, then bends left to reach the sound. A sign at the right reminds drivers that an off-road vehicle permit is required to drive on the ramp.

End of message.

bodyText:
Ramps are subject to closure. For the most current status of beach access ramps, go to https://go.nps.gov/beachaccess.

Pamlico Sound is one of the largest estuarine ecosystems in the United States of America. The water in the sound is shallow, relative warm and calm, brackish, and teeming with biodiversity. Access to the Pamlico Sound provides a variety of recreation opportunities: bait-fishing, crabbing, kayaking, kiteboarding, nature viewing, stand-up paddling, wading, and wind surfing to name a few.

Besides enjoying the waters of the sound, be on the lookout for birds like great blue herons, white ibises, snowy egrets, rare white pelicans, and even American bald eagles-who make rare appearances on the forest borders.

Know Before You Go

The seashore is an enjoyable place for swimming, but rough surf and rip currents can turn a fun visit into a frightening one. Tides, waves, and winds constantly barrage these barrier islands. Even at the shore's edge, crashing waves can pick you up and throw you to the sandy bottom causing injuries.

Off-road Vehicle Use


For beaches open to off-road-vehicle use, an off-road vehicle permit is required. Annual permits (from date of purchase) are $120 and 10-day permits are $50. Vehicles must be licensed, insured and registered; you must present your driver's license and vehicle registration. Permits must be purchased online at Recreation.gov

bodyText:

Beach Access Ramp 45 provides pedestrians coming from Cape Point Campground access to the beach on the western side of Cape Hatteras throughout the year.

The path is approximately 1½-mile from the roundabout to the beach. After the first bend in the path, it does cross the Inside Road, so be sure to watch for off-road vehicles traveling down that route from either direction.

Off-road Vehicle Use


For beaches open to off-road-vehicle use, an off-road vehicle permit is required. Annual permits (from date of purchase) are $120 and 10-day permits are $50. Vehicles must be licensed, insured and registered; you must present your driver's license and vehicle registration. Permits must be purchased online at Recreation.gov
audioDescription:
Beach Access Ramp 45
66 words (Â¾ minute)
From Cape Point Campground, this wide path leads past a roundabout and out over the dunes to the left to the beach. About 500 feet down the path, and just after the the bend to the left and the first dune climb, the path crosses Inside Road. Watch for vehicles coming from either direction before crossing the 30-foot-wide route and continuing down the path.

End of message.

images.altText: Trail sign pointing where the nature trail goes.
images.caption: Trail through the preserve

bodyText:
Springer's Point Nature Preserve is only accessible by foot or bicycle, and parking is prohibited on the road and private driveways. The trail and reserve are owned and operated by the North Carolina Coastal Land Trust. Encompassing more than 120 acres, the preserve is home to maritime forest, tidal red cedar forest, salt marsh, wet grasslands, and sound-front beach.

In 1718, the pirate Blackbeard camped in this area in the days leading up to his defeat and death. The water off Springer's Point-called Teach's Hole-is known to be where the final battle between Blackbeard and the British Royal Navy occurred. Now, a pleasant stroll through the maritime forest leads out to views of Ocracoke Inlet and Cape Lookout National Seashore beyond.
audioDescription:
Springer's Point Nature Preserve
45 words (Â½ minute)
The trailhead located off of Loop Road is marked by a sign that reads "North Carolina Coastal Land Trust Springer's Point Nature Preserve." A walk along the trail leads you through maritime forest and wet grasslands out to the salt marsh and sound-front beach.

End of message.

title: US Navy Beach Jumpers Marker
listingDescription: The US Navy Beach Jumpers-an elite group of enlisted men and officers-were sent to the amphibious training base located on Ocracoke Island between 1943 and 1944. During this time period, residents were not allowed on the beaches due to the deception trainings taking place just off-shore. Once trained, the US Navy Beach Jumpers were deployed to aide in the war taking place in the Pacific.

images.altText: Side of the marker detailing the beach jumpers.
images.caption: Marker stone side on beach jumpers

bodyText: The US Navy Beach Jumpers-an elite group of enlisted men and officers-were sent to the amphibious training base located on Ocracoke Island between 1943 and 1944. During this time period, residents were not allowed on the beaches due to the deception trainings taking place just off-shore. Once trained, the US Navy Beach Jumpers were deployed to aide in the war taking place in the Pacific.
audioDescription:
US Navy Beach Jumpers Marker
73 words (Â¾ minute)
This black-granite mark has etching on both sides. On one side are images of amphibious boats, US Navy Beach Jumpers patch, US Navy seal, a heritage trail seal, and an image of Lieutenant Douglas Fairbanks, Junior. The other side has images of the US Navy Beach Jumpers patch, another military patch, and a drawing of what the training base at Loop Shack Hill looked like. Nearby are cedar trees and NC-12.

End of message.

title: Wright Brothers National Memorial
listingDescription: Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903.With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever. Today, what the brothers achieved here is commemorated and memorialized.

images.altText: Marker of the first flight's landing location.
images.caption: First flight landing spot

bodyText:
Wind, sand, and a dream of flight brought Wilbur and Orville Wright to Kitty Hawk, North Carolina where, after four years of scientific experimentation, they achieved the first successful airplane flights on December 17, 1903.

With courage and perseverance, these self-taught engineers relied on teamwork and application of the scientific process. What they achieved changed our world forever.

Today, what the brothers achieved here is commemorated and memorialized.

For more information visit the website or the Wright Brothers National Memorial section of the NPS Mobile App.
audioDescription:
Wright Brothers National Memorial
49 words (Â½ minute)
This National Park Service site is where Wilbur and Orville Wright tested their flight theories until they finally succeeded in the world's first powered, controlled, heavier-than-air flights. Now, the site where they did all this work is memorialized and preserved for anyone to visit, and be inspired!

End of message.
